title: P0011-06 RfA for Introduction of MK-0616 Decanoate API from Q2 2025 at the MSD Ireland (Ballydine) p
document_type: Requests for Approval and Site Reports
metadata_json:
{"compliance_id": "99aafa33-db2c-f011-a373-0050568a2d1a", "document_type": "Requests for Approval and Site Reports", "document_url": "https://data.epa.ie/leap/api/v1/LicenseeReturns/byid?lr_id=99aafa33-db2c-f011-a373-0050568a2d1a", "title": "P0011-06 RfA for Introduction of MK-0616 Decanoate API from Q2 2025 at the MSD Ireland (Ballydine) p", "description": "Dear Ms. McMullen,  
  
Please find attached processing information in support of the planned introduction of the MK-0616 Decanoate API (active pharmaceutical ingredient) process at the MSD Ireland (Ballydine) facility.  
  
The MK-0616 Decanoate API process is the final process step onsite in the manufacture of a new medication which can be taken to lower patient lipoprotein cholesterol reducing the risk of a cardiovascular event.  
  
The planned introduction of the MK-0616 Decanoate API process will commence with a pilot production campaign in our Fac01 facility from the start of June 2025, followed by further pilot, validation and commercial supply production campaigns during and from 2026.  
  
The process chemistry and reaction types employed in the manufacture of the MK-0616 Decanoate API process are of a similar nature to those already conducted at MSD Ireland (Ballydine).  
  
The manufacturing facility will be unchanged with the exception of minor modifications to existing equipment.  All modifications to existing equipment will be covered by the site’s existing change control procedures.  
  
Attached for your reference are details of all new raw materials, intermediates, products, waste streams etc., used or generated during the proposed production of MK-0616 Decanoate API.  Existing treatment facilities are adequately sized to treat all gaseous and liquid wastes.  
  
We trust that this proposal meets with your approval.

Request for Actions regarding Odour Complaints and request for Fugitive Emissions Assessment

\\n

Dear Jonathan Keane,

\\n

EPA has recently received several complaints about chemical odours, poor air quality and possible health effects in the vicinity of Versiv Composites Ltd.  EPA takes the view that these complaints, though not confirmed in real time by EPA inspectors, are nonetheless credible and therefore potential sources need to be investigated and identified. Any pathways for uncontrolled emissions that are identified by these investigations must be closed off as quickly as possible using the best available approaches.

\\n

You are required to conduct the following actions to provide further information in relation to the potential for uncontrolled emissions from your facility:

\\n

1             Production Schedule and Associated Processes

\\n

The Agency requests the production schedule and associated processes that occurred on the date of 8th April 2025.

\\n

2             Feasibility Study

\\n

Based on point source monitoring results, the Agency requests submission of a feasibility study into the redirection of ducting from PSA 3 and PSA 5 directly into the TO Abatement system.

\\n

3             Fugitive Emissions Assessment

\\n

EPA requires you to arrange for a survey of minor and fugitive air emissions to identify any uncontrolled or fugitive emission pathways that may be responsible for the reported air quality issues. The survey should be conducted by a suitably qualified and experienced contractor and should include the following methods

\\n
    \\n
  • Optical Gas Imaging
    • \\n
  • Flame Ionisation Detection
    • \\n
\\n

Measurements should be conducted, as a minimum, at and around:

\\n
    \\n
  1. major and minor emission points
    2. \\n
  2. leaks from building fabric, ducting and egress points
    3. \\n
  3. leaks from abatement structures
    4. \\n
\\n

To inform the reporting and interpretative process, you are to compile a record of production activity during the survey and for one calendar day before and after the survey inclusive;

\\n

The survey should be conducted during times of active production processes and when activities involving emissions via minor emission points are taking place. As a minimum, at least one full production run shall be monitored for each type of production process conducted on site.

\\n

Please provide details of the appointed contractor and their methodology for the survey as a Request for EPA Approval prior to commencement. Please also give a minimum of 24 hours notice of commencement of the monitoring work to allow EPA to attend for part or all of the onsite works.

\\n

The results shall be reported to EPA, with full interpretation by the contractor, within 6 weeks from the date of EPA approval to commence.

\\n

If you have any quires regarding this direction, please email to CorkOEEIndustrialEnforcementExt@epa.ie.

\\n

Yours sincerely,

\\n

Peter Cunningham

\\n

Office of Environmental Enforcement, Southwest Region

\\n

A video conference meeting was held between the EPA and Uisce Éireann (UÉ) on 08/04/2025 from 12:00 to 12:50 approx.

\\n

During the meeting UÉ gave an update to the EPA on the phased upgrades being undertaken at Ringsend WWTP and a summary of treatment plant performance for Q1 2025.

\\n

Works on Hybrid II upgrades and sludge treatment facilities are progressing as scheduled with all primary aspects of the upgrade project due for completion by end 2025. A programme of ancillary works connected with the overall upgrade project is also being progressed with most completion dates falling within 2025.

\\n

A summary of plant performance was given. UÉ are aiming for 104 compliance samples to be taken during 2025. 10 no. samples records were recorded in the Q1 Update under compliance investigation (CI000025).  Compliance results were unavailable for the first three weeks of January. This was attributed to operational reasons (plant shutdowns) and management changeover. It is UÉ’s intention to make up the shortfall to 104 compliance samples over the year. It was acknowledged that there is a risk that TN and TP average limits may not be achieved this year. UÉ expect that performance will improve across all parameters once remaining upgraded SBR blocks come back on-line and as average air temperatures increase through the year. UÉ confirmed that higher than expected load on the plant (2.17 PE in 2024) was expected to continue increasing in 2025 and is also affecting treatment performance. Issues with the aeration system in the Capital Upgrade treatment block were also cited as a compounding factor in treatment performance and should be resolved by end April 2025.

\\n

The EPA instructed Uisce Éireann to carry out all actions necessary to comply with the waste water discharge licence.
